metadata.title: Chile Ridge Aeromagnetic Survey from Puerto Montt
metadata.description: Aeromagnetic data collected in 1990 west of southern Chile, 99°-73°W, 49°-37°S, published by Tebbens et al. (1997; https://doi.org/10.1029/96JB02581) and Tebbens and Cande (1997; https://doi.org/10.1029/96JB02582), used for determining relative motion of the Nazca and Antarctic plates.
keywords: Aeromagnetic data; Nazca plate; Antarctic plate
references: Tebbens, S.F., Cande, S.C., Kovacs, L., Parra, J.C., LaBrecque, J.L. and Vergara, H., 1997. The Chile ridge: A tectonic framework. Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth, 102(B6), pp.12035-12059.
Tebbens, S.F. and Cande, S.C., 1997. Southeast Pacific tectonic evolution from early Oligocene to present. Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth, 102(B6), pp.12061-12084.

data.title: Chile Ridge Aeromagnetic Survey from Puerto Montt

metadata.title: Supporting material for "Enhancing debris flow warning via machine learning feature reduction and model selection"
metadata.description:
Supporting material list:

0, Features that calculate based on Provost et al 2017, Chmiel et al. 2021, and Zhou et al 2024; 

1, Manually labeld debris flow start and end time;

2, Source code for the machine learning model that used in our work;

3, Trained model that descripted in our work;

 

Note: Please check our GitHub codebase for the latest changes.
https://github.com/Qi-Zhou-Geo/Flow-Alert.git

journal.title: Enhancing debris flow warning via machine learning feature reduction and model selection

metadata.notes:
Provost, Floriane, Clément Hibert, and J‐P. Malet. "Automatic classification of endogenous landslide seismicity using the Random Forest supervised classifier." Geophysical Research Letters 44, no. 1 (2017): 113-120.

Chmiel, Małgorzata, Fabian Walter, Michaela Wenner, Zhen Zhang, Brian W. McArdell, and Clement Hibert. "Machine learning improves debris flow warning." Geophysical Research Letters 48, no. 3 (2021): e2020GL090874.

Zhou, Qi, Hui Tang, Jens M. Turowski, Jean Braun, Michael Dietze, Fabian Walter, Ci‐Jian Yang, and Sophie Lagarde. "Benford's law as debris flow detector in seismic signals." Journal of Geophysical Research: Earth Surface 129, no. 9 (2024): e2024JF007691.

data.title: Supporting material for "Enhancing debris flow warning via machine learning feature reduction and model selection"

metadata.title: TMY files for Norway based on CERRA data from 1991-2020
metadata.description:
This dataset includes TMY files for all municipalities in Norway, produced in conjunction with the Norwegian standard NS 3031:2025 Energy performance of buildings Calculation of energy and power demand. The files are based on CERRA data from 1991-2020, and produces using a TMY3 type methodology, where the FS weighing is skewed towards temperatures during the winter months (October to March).  The files represents a statistically typical year meant for energy calculations of buildings, and are therefore not suited for evaluating extreme conditions.

The repository contains:

  • EPW-files - zipped collection of .epw-files
    • The most common file format for climate data for energy simulations applicable to most programs
  • CSV-Files - zipped collections of .csv files 
    • Climate data on comma separated format as well as Excel for easy access
    • This format includes all the neccesary data for energy calculations, but less data than the EPW files. 
    • File headers are in Norwegian
  • NetCDF-files - a zipped collections of .nc files 
    • one for each location
  • Datasheets - a pdf file of datasheets as well as a zip files of individual data 
    • A collection of datasheets containing a comparison of TMYs with the data source as well as referance data
    • The datasheets contain Norwegian text
  • Overview of Error metrics - ZIP files containing plots of error metrics  
    • Error metrics mapped to a map of Norway, for visualization purposes
  • Changelog - a txt file
    • a overview of changes in the dataset since 1.0

The contents of the repository is produced by The Norwegian Meteorological Office (MET) and The Norwegian University og Life Science (NMBU), Department of Building- and Environmental Technology.

The funding for the project was provided in equal parts by Norwegian Building Authority (Direktoratet for byggkvalitet), ENOVA and the Norwegian Water Resources and Energy Directorate (NVE).

The data is provided 'as is', without warranty of any kind, express or implied. In no event shall the authors be liable for any claim, damages or other liability.
references: CERRA: Ridal, Martin, et al. "CERRA, the Copernicus European Regional Reanalysis system." Quarterly Journal of the Royal Meteorological Society (2024). https://doi.org/10.1002/qj.4764
seNorge: Lussana, Cristian, et al. "seNorge_2018, daily precipitation, and temperature datasets over Norway." Earth System Science Data 11.4 (2019): 1531-1551-1551.

SunPoint: Rabault, J., et al. "Data fusion of complementary data sources using Machine Learning enables higher accuracy Solar Resource Maps." arXiv preprint arXiv:2501.04381 (2025). https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2501.04381
Zippenfenig, P. (2023). Open-Meteo.com Weather API [Computer software]. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/ZENODO.7970649
Wilcox, S, & Marion, W (2008). Users Manual for TMY3 Data Sets (Revised). https://doi.org/10.2172/928611

data.title: TMY files for Norway based on CERRA data from 1991-2020

metadata.title: Statistical tools for finite rotations
metadata.description: The file fit_jyr.tar.zip contains software for statistics of finite plate rotations as documented by Royer and Chang (1991; https://doi.org/10.1029/91JB00897) and Kirkwood et al. (1999; https://doi.org/10.1046/j.1365-246X.1999.00787.x), formerly distributed by university of Virginia.  The file was emailed by Jean-Yves Royer in January 2020.
references: Royer, J.Y. and Chang, T., 1991. Evidence for relative motions between the Indian and Australian plates during the last 20 my from plate tectonic reconstructions: Implications for the deformation of the Indo‐Australian plate. Journal of Geophysical Research: Solid Earth, 96(B7), pp.11779-11802.

Kirkwood, B.H., Royer, J.Y., Chang, T.C. and Gordon, R.G., 1999. Statistical tools for estimating and combining finite rotations and their uncertainties. Geophysical Journal International, 137(2), pp.408-428.

metadata.title: THE ASTARTEUSKALI DOSSIER  XINA MORA AS THE GENOTYPIC REINCARNATION OF ASTARTE
metadata.description:
This dossier explores the hypothesis that singer Xina Mora represents the genotypic reincarnation of the goddess Astarte, drawing parallels between her essence, her multidisciplinary talents, and the mythical figure of the Phoenician-Canaanite deity. Through an anthropological, mythological, and biogenetic approach, we will analyze the traits that connect her presence in modernity to the incarnation of an ancient goddess.

The title "The Astarteuskali Dossier" reflects the fusion of Astarte, the goddess of fertility, war, and love, with Euskali, a concept evoking the primordial essence of the Earth and its divine lineage. This union suggests a sacred reincarnation with ancestral roots and cosmic projection.

data.title: THE ASTARTEUSKALI DOSSIER  XINA MORA AS THE GENOTYPIC REINCARNATION OF ASTARTE

metadata.title: PKPPKP Global Stacks for resolution of fine-scale structure of the Earth's mantle
metadata.description: The figure shows stacks for the P'P' time window for seven 200-km thick layers throughout Earth's mantle in a 10deg x 10deg bin. Location of the bin is indicated on the top of each page and the location is shown on the small global map insert (green square). The location of the Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces is indicated by read areas. Depths centred are 100, 600 , 1100, 1600, 2100, 2600, 2889 km.  Background shows the earliest scattering times of P'•P' from the CMB (1720s) to the surface. The appropriate time is shown by the thick red vertical line. Mean of the stack is shown by blue line with the standard deviation shown as grey shading. Amplitudes are normalized to the maximum amplitude in each panel.  Green line indicates a 1D synthtic model as described in Rost and Frost, EPSL, 2025.

creators.name: Rost, Sebastian
creators.affiliation: University of Leeds, School of Earth and Environment

data.title: PKPPKP Global Stacks for resolution of fine-scale structure of the Earth's mantle

metadata.title: CÁLCULO DE EROSÃO DA BACIA HIDROGRÁFICA DO CURU, CEARÁ USANDO GOOGLE EARTH ENGINE
metadata.description:
A integração do Google Earth Engine (GEE) tem revolucionado estudos nos
mais variados segmentos científicos da sociedade. No semiárido brasileiro, sua aplicação
está possibilitando uma série de estudos que antes não existiam, como no estudo de
erosão, por exemplo. Destacando a bacia hidrográfica do rio Curu, localizada no Ceará,
que é caracterizada por precipitações irregulares, solos em vulnerabilidade e intensa
crescente atividade antrópica. Diante do presente contexto, o uso de ferramentas como
GEE é essencial para identificar áreas críticas de erosão e entender seus padrões.

journal.title: II CONGRESSO NACIONAL DE PROJETO, PESQUISA E EXTENSÃO

meeting.title: I CONGRESSO INTERNACIONAL DE INOVAÇÕES E TECNOLOGIA  AGRÍCOLAS

data.title: CÁLCULO DE EROSÃO DA BACIA HIDROGRÁFICA DO CURU, CEARÁ USANDO GOOGLE EARTH ENGINE

metadata.title: Bacteriophage-Clostridioides difficile interactions: From the impact of phages on bacterial virulence to new therapeutic strategies.
metadata.description:
Clostridioides difficile infections (CDI) are a major cause of nosocomial post-antibiotic diarrhoea. The pathogen's virulence is based on its production of toxins that alter the intestinal barrier, leading to inflammation that upsets the balance of the microbiota. Its ability to sporulate favours dissemination in hospital environments, and its resilience to antibiotics leads to recurrent infections.

Bacteriophages are natural predators, specific to a single bacterium, or even a single strain. They offer promising therapeutic prospects and are already being used in osteoarticular and pulmonary infections. Interactions between phages and bacteria are numerous and bacterial gene expression, thus influencing pathogenicity.

The aim of this thesis is to detail the numerous therapeutic applications of phages and to explore the opportunities offered by the latest bioengineering technologies to develop phages adapted to the infectious context of CDI and specifically targeting pathogenic C. difficile strains within the microbiota. Each player in the infectious site, as well as coevolutionary dynamics, will need to be considered to guarantee the long-term effectiveness of phage therapy.

Implementing this innovative approach requires interdisciplinary coordination combining microbiology, bioengineering and clinical science to respect practical constraints while integrating fundamental knowledge. This operational flexibility will be crucial in producing effective and sustainable phage therapy.

data.title: Bacteriophage-Clostridioides difficile interactions: From the impact of phages on bacterial virulence to new therapeutic strategies.
